The parents of a Derry man who was killed ten years ago tonight have voiced support for tougher sentencing in the most serious dangerous driving cases.Martin ‘Marty’ Gallagher was  years old when he was killed in a hit and run collision at Racecourse Road as he walked home after celebrating Derry’s Halloween festival .The driver, Jonathan Francis McGonagle, was drunk, speeding and had drugs in his system. He was jailed for three years in December  for causing death by dangerous driving and spent another three years on license.Marty’s parents, Martin and Elizabeth, have had to live with the consequences of the driver’s actions for the rest of their lives. It has also impacted on the lives of his brothers Richard and Ryan, and sisters Michelle and Anne.This week the Department of Justice launched a public consultation into a Sentencing Review. One of the offences up for debate are those “which may result in death, including causing death by dangerous driving”.It seeks the public’s views on whether the current maximum sentence of  years should be increased to le imprisonment or increased to a higher fixed number of years.The Department confirmed to the Derry News that a decision can be taken on these legislative changes in the absence of a minister.The Gallagher family are supportive of le imprisonment being introduced for such offences.Speaking to the Derry News yesterday, Marty’s father described him as a “great son” who got on with everybody and raised a lot of money for charities through his running.Martin said his son would’ve been a good footballer and got involved in competitive running when he was  or -years-old.On the day Marty was killed, his father was working and didn’t see him before he went into town but said he was joking about with his mother before he left.Martin and his we slept on the third floor of the house with Marty and Ryan on the bottom floor. About am Ryan burst through the door saying, “he’s dead, he’s dead”, and when they asked who they were left in a state of shock. “The man killed Martin at am and then went on to a party,” Mr Gallagher said. googletag.cmd.push  Photo: Marty Gallagher with friend Barry Smith after London marathon No closure Martin and Elizabeth were initially asked to call to the Racecourse Road to identy him but a PSNI sergeant then said it wouldn’t be possible because it was a crime scene. The police sergeant, who still keeps in touch with the family and whom Mr Gallagher described as a “good man”, wanted to spare them the trauma of seeing Marty’s injuries.The following day they were also advised against seeing their son at the morgue but when the coffin was brought home Mr Gallagher said they were in disbelief and it brought “no closure”. “You’re wondering was that Martin and waiting for him to walk through the door,” he added.The man responsible for his death appeared in court for the first time on Martin’s birthday, February . He was sentenced in December  with police saying it was one of the quicker cases of its kind to pass through the courts.“First of all we tried for murder and they wouldn’t give it to us,” Martin recalled. “Then we tried for manslaughter and they wouldn’t give us that either, why, I don’t know.“I think the reason it went through so quick was because the girl testied who was in the back and actually shouted to the driver, ‘Jesus, there’s a fella crossing the road’. Martin was about a foot away from reaching the footpath.“That person who killed Martin was full of drugs and drink but the police couldn’t say when he took the drugs.“We were hoping that he would get at least fourteen years. What they’re trying to do now in England, Scotland and Wales is bring in le for le, but they’re not bringing it in in Northern Ireland.When told the news of proposals that are now on the table in NI to Increase the maximum sentence to le imprisonment for the three serious driving offences resulting in death or grievous bodily injury, Martin was fully supportive, believing it may be the deterrent needed to make drivers take more care.This would mirror the current maximum sentence available for offences such as manslaughter, rape, shooting or wounding with intent to commit grievous bodily harm. Public support Two months ago the same man responsible for their son’s death was convicted of a number of driving offences but was given a suspended sentence.“Ten years later he has never said he was sorry,” Martin stated, “I will never forgive him.” An emotional Martin said, “it’s like part of our le is gone,” as he implored anyone ever considering drink-driving to think about the suffering of families affected by such tragedies.“You live from day-to-day for your other children. You might’ve seen the ad on TV about the man living with depression who pulls the mask off at night, you just put a front on for people.“It gets no easier over ten years, people say it gets easier, it doesn’t, you learn to live with it just that’s it. If you didn’t have a good family and marriage, it would wreck your family.”And every time he crosses paths with his son’s killer it makes it worse, he added.Support from the local community has helped to lt the family’s spirits over the years. Last weekend  members of Foyle Valley Athletics Club ran the Dublin marathon in memory of Marty.One of the founding members of the club, Harry McNulty, ran his st and final marathon on the day – Marty was a prodigy of Harry’s when he joined Foyle Valley.“With Marty’s run every year we’ve raised about pound, for Derry charities. Over , people turned out at the start of the month.“It’s great to see what they thought of Martin and the money going to charity.“Last year we gave Altnagelvin a bed and it has Martin’s name on it but we try to spread it out. “The support gives us a lt and it just shows you what people thought of Martin,” Mr Gallagher concluded. . The parents of a Derry man who was killed ten years ago tonight have voiced support for tougher sentencing in the most serious dangerous driving cases.Martin ‘Marty’ Gallagher was  years old when he was killed in a hit and run collision at Racecourse Road as he walked home after celebrating Derry’s Halloween festival .The driver, Jonathan Francis McGonagle, was drunk, speeding and had drugs in his system. He was jailed for three years in December  for causing death by dangerous driving and spent another three years on license.Marty’s parents, Martin and Elizabeth, have had to live with the consequences of the driver’s actions for the rest of their lives. It has also impacted on the lives of his brothers Richard and Ryan, and sisters Michelle and Anne.This week the Department of Justice launched a public consultation into a Sentencing Review. One of the offences up for debate are those “which may result in death, including causing death by dangerous driving”.It seeks the public’s views on whether the current maximum sentence of  years should be increased to le imprisonment or increased to a higher fixed number of years.The Department confirmed to the Derry News that a decision can be taken on these legislative changes in the absence of a minister.The Gallagher family are supportive of le imprisonment being introduced for such offences.Speaking to the Derry News yesterday, Marty’s father described him as a “great son” who got on with everybody and raised a lot of money for charities through his running.Martin said his son would’ve been a good footballer and got involved in competitive running when he was  or -years-old.On the day Marty was killed, his father was working and didn’t see him before he went into town but said he was joking about with his mother before he left.Martin and his we slept on the third floor of the house with Marty and Ryan on the bottom floor. About am Ryan burst through the door saying, “he’s dead, he’s dead”, and when they asked who they were left in a state of shock. “The man killed Martin at am and then went on to a party,” Mr Gallagher said. googletag.cmd.push  Photo: Marty with friend Barry Smith at London Marathon ‘No closure’ They were initially asked to call to the Racecourse Road to identy him but a PSNI sergeant then said it wouldn’t be possible because it was a crime scene. The police sergeant, who still keeps in touch with the family and whom Mr Gallagher described as a “good man”, wanted to spare them the trauma of seeing Marty’s injuries.The following day they were also advised against seeing their son at the morgue but when the coffin was brought home Mr Gallagher said they were in disbelief and it brought “no closure”. “You’re wondering was that Martin and waiting for him to walk through the door,” he added.The man responsible for his death appeared in court for the first time on Martin’s birthday, February . He was sentenced in December  with police saying it was one of the quicker cases of its kind to pass through the courts.“First of all we tried for murder and they wouldn’t give it to us,” Martin recalled. “Then we tried for manslaughter and they wouldn’t give us that either, why, I don’t know.“I think the reason it went through so quick was because the girl testied who was in the back and actually shouted to the driver, ‘Jesus, there’s a fella crossing the road’. Martin was about a foot away from reaching the footpath.“That person who killed Martin was full of drugs and drink but the police couldn’t say when he took the drugs.“We were hoping that he would get at least fourteen years. What they’re trying to do now in England, Scotland and Wales is bring in le for le, but they’re not bringing it in in Northern Ireland.When told the news of proposals that are now on the table in NI to Increase the maximum sentence to le imprisonment for the three serious driving offences resulting in death or grievous bodily injury, Martin was fully supportive, believing it may be the deterrent needed to make drivers take more care.This would mirror the current maximum sentence available for offences such as manslaughter, rape, shooting or wounding with intent to commit grievous bodily harm. Public support Two months ago the same man responsible for their son’s death was convicted of a number of driving offences but was given a suspended sentence.“Ten years later he has never said he was sorry,” Martin stated, “I will never forgive him.” An emotional Martin said, “it’s like part of our le is gone,” as he implored anyone ever considering drink-driving to think about the suffering of families affected by such tragedies.“You live from day-to-day for your other children. You might’ve seen the ad on TV about the man living with depression who pulls the mask off at night, you just put a front on for people.“It gets no easier over ten years, people say it gets easier, it doesn’t, you learn to live with it just that’s it. If you didn’t have a good family and marriage, it would wreck your family.”And every time he crosses paths with his son’s killer it makes it worse, he added.Support from the local community has helped to lt the family’s spirits over the years. Last weekend  members of Foyle Valley Athletics Club ran the Dublin marathon in memory of Marty.One of the founding members of the club, Harry McNulty, ran his st and final marathon on the day – Marty was a prodigy of Harry’s when he joined Foyle Valley.“With Marty’s run every year we’ve raised about pound, for Derry charities. Over , people turned out at the start of the month.“It’s great to see what they thought of Martin and the money going to charity.“Last year we gave Altnagelvin a bed and it has Martin’s name on it but we try to spread it out. “The support gives us a lt and it just shows you what people thought of Martin,” Mr Gallagher concluded. . Charlie and Olivia have been revealed as the naughtiest names amongst children in Northern Ireland, whilst children named Harry and Isla are considered to be the most well behaved, according to new research amongst children, parents and teachers throughout the country.Children and teachers agree that Charlies are the most likely to misbehave in the country, with almost a fth of those researched claiming children with the moniker are the naughtiest.When it comes to girls, it’s Olivias that teachers and parents associate most strongly with mischief, although girls’ names generally are considered to be less naughty than boys’ names. Olivia ranks at number eight on the complete list.Interestingly, it’s Emilys that children in the country expect to be the naughtiest, demonstrating the dfering opinions between the generations.When it comes to well behaved children, boys named Harry top the list in Northern Ireland, according to the research commissioned byMy Nametags, a leading manufacturer of durable sticker and iron-on name labels.It’s Isla that comes out on top of the behaviour chart for girls, with none of those surveyed expecting children with this name to be misbehaved.Boys named Harry are considered to be shyest in the class, with their peers agreeing children with this name tend to be amongst the most introverted.By contrast, girls named Ella are seen as the most confident children in the country, with none of the children surveyed considering them to be shy. For boys, it’s Leos who are assumed to be the most self-assured.The study, which analysed the opinions of , teachers, children and parents in the UK, found that Brits are quick to make assumptions about a child based on their first name, with strong stereotypes associated with each of the names featured in this year’s top  baby names list. googletag.cmd.push The national results found that children named George are considered by both adults and their peers to be the most intelligent in class, with over one in  believing this is the most intellectual name from this year’s top  boys names list. They also associated it with kindness, with teachers and children regarding boys named George as kind-hearted.According to teachers, Isabella tops the list for girls when it comes to intelligence. However, children’s attitudes of Isabellas dfer drastically, with over one in  children assuming those named Isabella will be spoilt, based on their first name alone. For boys, its Harrys that children expect to be spoilt, whereas teachers consider those named Oliver to be the most indulged.  Norths Top  Naughtiest Boys Names . Charlie. Muhammad. Oliver. Oscar. Foreglen coach Philip Muldoon is happy for his team to take on the underdogs tag again as they prepare to face Monaghan champions Magheracloone on Sunday.The O’Briens will travel to the lion’s den of Inniskeen full of confidence after making a mockery of the bookies and upsetting the odds to comprehensively defeat league champions and parish rivals Claudy in the championship final two weeks ago.Their counterparts claimed county silverware the week previous, with a convincing performance of their own in a - to - victory against Donaghmoyne.Foreglen’s opponents on Sunday come with an interesting back story.  months ago, a disused mine collapsed in the area where the club grounds were located. Two days later, two further sinkholes appeared, and a huge split broke the pitch in half and spread to the clubhouse and car park. The grounds were immediately shut down, and the misery was compounded a few weeks later when the club were relegated from senior football for the first time in  years.This season they have made use of alternate venues as the work continues to re-establish their own home, with a GoFundMe page raising tens of thousands towards the project. The club – who have appeared in six of the last  Monaghan Senior Club Championship finals, with the most recent appearance in  – have secured their position back in the senior ranks for next season, but first they must deal with the business of Ulster.For Foreglen, it’s a familiar position. At the start of the Derry championship they were ranked as dark horses, but were few people’s out and out favourites. Bar a first round replay against Faughanvale they barely faltered on the way to the showpiece, but still there were few in their corner against Claudy. It mattered little as they held the Mitchel’s to one score – a free – in the second half to claim a - to - win. O’Brien’s coach Muldoon believes they can take serious confidence not just from the result, but from the nature of the performance.“I think after the replay with Faughanvale, as the championship went on our confidence just got better and better and we’re going into this game now off the back of a big performance,” the Ballinderry man told the Derry Post. “My team talks are very brief before a game because we do the work in training. The boys know on the day what they have to do, who they’re marking, what the plan is for kick outs – it’s all organised.“We’ll sit down this week and look at Magheracloone. There’s not a lot of information or videos out there but we’ll get our planning done and be ready for the challenge. It will probably be a case of giving it five or ten minutes and then making the switches that we need to.“It’s bonus territory for us, and it’s unknown territory too. We know they’re going to be a very good, strong side and we’re expecting a tough challenge but it’s one that we’re all looking forward to.”From the scenes on the pitch in Celtic Park after their victory two weeks ago to the social media posts from Foreglen clubhouse in the following days, the togetherness of the whole community has come to the fore. Even as a man not from the club, Muldoon said it was something special, and something they’d like to repay. “After the final whistle I stood back and saw my two boys running onto the pitch in their Foreglen tops and I shed a tear. They’re a small parish, and I know a lot of them are the same, but in that clubhouse on the Sunday night, I’d never seen a crowd like it. “We said to the lads last week that when it came to Ulster there was a choice to train a few times or put the heads down and give it a rattle. We want to set an example for the county and to be fair they’ve put the shoulder to the wheel for their community.“It’s a day out for everyone to jump on a bus together and head down. The whole favourites thing is all part of the build-up, but we won’t read too much into it this time either.”Both played five championship matches on their way to their provincial titles, with the Monaghan side both scoringand concedingmore than Foreglen, who scored - and conceded -. Even with county level players like Gavin Doogan and Tomas Freeman on the other side, Muldoon reiterated his faith in the O’Brien’s defence, and he feels the forward line can take confidence knowing that they will get opportunities.“In training and in all our games we have the same set up – it’s man to man marking, no sweepers and no hiding places, and we’ve no plans to change that,” explained the coach. “In the build-up to the final nobody was giving our defence any credit, it was all about the Claudy forwards, and vice versa about our attack.“Our defence is tight, the boys talk to one another, you have the likes of Oisin and Shane Duffy in there and they’re all told what to be doing before the game. It’s a quality he feels will stand them in good stead come Sunday afternoon.“I sat down on the Saturday night before the game with Claudy and rang some of them young lads and said to them that I knew what they were feeling, and they’d got us there through talent and enthusiasm. They worked hard all year in the gym, but they had to go out and treat it as any other game,” he explained. “In fairness to them they did, and I thought every one of them were immense. “Now getting the chance to play in Ulster – it’s a brilliant experience for them young cubs and it’s one that will definitely stand to them.”  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Them boys don’t have the cover of a sweeper, but they do their job, they back themselves against their man and they have confidence as a unit.”For the seasoned professionals like Oisin Duffy, Mark McCormick and Kevin O’Connor, the pressure of an Ulster quarter-final won’t weigh too heavy on the shoulders, but Muldoon said he is particularly delighted that the younger squad members, like Liam O’Hara, Sean, Cahir and Caolan O’Connor, have all shown that they can handle the mental pressure of the big occasion. It’s a quality he feels will stand them in good stead come Sunday afternoon.“I sat down on the Saturday night before the game with Claudy and rang some of them young lads and said to them that I knew what they were feeling, and they’d got us there through talent and enthusiasm. They worked hard all year in the gym, but they had to go out and treat it as any other game,” he explained. “In fairness to them they did, and I thought every one of them were immense. “Now getting the chance to play in Ulster – it’s a brilliant experience for them young cubs and it’s one that will definitely stand to them.”  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Two best friends from Strabane have combined their knowledge and passion for alternative therapies by joining forces to launch their own wellness business, thanks to support from the Go For It programme in association with Derry City and Strabane District Council.This project is part funded by Invest Northern Ireland and the European Regional Development Fund under the Investment for Growth and Jobs Northern IrelandProgramme. Co. Tyrone mumpreneurs - Joanne Gallagher and Stephanie Rice – launched Good Vibes in their home town of Strabane in June this year, after identying a gap in the market for alternative and holistic treatments in the town. Joanne said, “I felt the benefits of alternative and holistic treatments personally and wanted to know more, so after much research I trained to become a Meditation Coach, Reiki Master and NLP Practitioner. “I have always been passionate about wellness and in recent years have practised privately, offering holistic treatments such as reiki and meditation to clients who experience symptoms including anxiety, stress, aches and pains, among other things.“I feel passionately about the benefits of alternative therapy and since Stephanie, my best friend from secondary school also practised within the field, it just made sense for us to join forces.”Joanne and Stephanie offer a iety of alternative therapies, including reflexology, massage, meditation and yoga in a safe and friendly environment that allows clients to explore which practice works best for them. Joanne and Stephanie welcome a wide range of clients to their studio, from alternative therapy veterans to those who are new to holistic healing techniques. Stephanie, who is a reflexologist, Indian head masseuse and Aromatherapy Specialist and plans to train as a yoga teacher next Spring. Said: “Helping others is something I have always loved doing. I am passionate about alternative therapies and have experienced first-hand the effect these, combined with the power of positivity, can have. “Opening my own business was something I had always dreamed of and with Joanne also working within the industry, it seemed like the perfect opportunity for us to partner up to bring the dream to le. Joanne and Stephanie turned their idea for a business into a reality after taking part in the Go For It Programme, which is delivered free of charge by a team of experienced business mentors through Northern Ireland’s wide network of enterprise agencies.The Go For It Programme, provides expert advice and help with developing a robust business plan to help turn people’s ideas for a business into a commercial enterprise.Stephanie commented, “We had the passion for health and wellbeing, but beyond our qualications and training we didn’t know how to put it all together into a sustainable business model. That’s where the Go For It Programme came in and really helped us. “The programme helped us with everything from marketing strategies to financial planning. The Business Advisors were very attentive and explained everything to us in great detail, and we both felt really informed and supported throughout the whole process. With the help of the programme, we were really supported to set up the business.Orla McNulty, business adviser with Strabane Enterprise Agency on behalf of Derry City and Strabane District Council, said, “It was a pleasure to assist Joanne and Stephanie in the start-up stage of their business. They have a real passion for health and wellbeing and that passion for helping others really underpins their business ethos. ““I sat down with Joanne and Stephanie and together we planned a clear strategy for their business start-up. A business plan was developed with detailed financial forecasts, marketing strategies and addressed legal issues.”“I’m delighted to see that the business is thriving for the ladies, with so many people availing of the fantastic services they are now providing in Strabane town centre. With their passion for health and wellbeing, their vast experience in alternative therapies and their specialist qualications, Joanne and Stephanie are well positioned within the marketplace and have a bright future ahead of them.”If you have a business idea you’d like to develop oryou are thinking about starting a business contact the Go For It team on    or visit: www.goforitni. googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. A NEW start business from Dungiven is in with a chance of winning a share of €,.IMAGene Ltd has been announced as one of the regional finalisrs of this year’s InterTradeIreland Seedcorn Investor Readiness Competition which has a substantial final cash prize.The Co Derry digital company is one of  companies from across the island which will compete across four regional heats beginning in November.Established by Mark Leonard, Janet Mitchell and Navein Madhavan in , IMAGene Ltd develops digital tools for the manufacturing industry to address productivity.The Northern Ireland final will take place at the the Europa Hotel, Belfast on November  and will see the Dungiven business go up against five other Ulster companies.Each business will deliver an investment pitch in front of an expert judging  comprising of venture capitalists, business angels and some of the island’s leading business leaders.Speaking about the regional finalists,Shane OHanlon, Funding for Growth Manager at InterTradeIrelandsaid: “I’m delighted to offer my congratulations to all those who have reached this crucial stage. The regional finalists have been successfully chosen based on their submission of their business plan and visual representation of their business idea. The standard of entries from Northern Ireland was very high and we look forward to seeing how the competition progresses.”As well as a substantial cash prize fund, participants benefit from promotional, business planning workshops and mentorship support throughout the competition.The regional finalists will receive an intensive one-day investment pitch masterclass facilitated by InterTradeIreland, to help polish their presentation skills. The regional winners will then be invited to pitch to a  of judges at the all-island final, taking place in Dublin on  November  with the overall winner and category winner announced that evening at an awards ceremony at Guinness Storehouse, Dublin.To date, InterTradeIreland has supported over , enterprising companies through the Seedcorn process. Romantic reunions have always captured our imaginations, from Tristan and Isolde, toHeathclf and Catherine Rick and Ilsa in Casablanca . There is something haunting about the idea of a lost love a relationship that never quite ran its natural course and could be reignited someday. Perhaps it’s not surprising that one in five people long to get back with an old flame, and now a new television show from ITV is searching for pining lovers in the Derry area. The team who make ‘Long Lost Family’ have been reuniting people with missing family members for a decade now they want to bring romantic soulmates together after years apart. googletag.cmd.push They have approached Derry Now for help, believing that the recent history of Northern Ireland may have indirectly resulted in a few star-crossed lovers. The turbulence of The Troubles and waves of migration to and from Northern Island in the latter part of the th century mean many couples may have been separated by circumstances. If this sounds like you, they want to hear your story. The programme idea was inspired by the story of KT Robbins, an American serviceman who fell in love with an eighteen-year-old French girl, Jeannine Ganaye in  and recently reunited with her after  years apart. The Derry area has provided similarly heart-warming stories in the past. Avril Trenklet and Bob Fanuce proved that true love never dies when they wed nearly  years after first meeting. Local factory girl, Avril first met US Marine Bob in  when he was stationed at a Naval base in Derry. After a whirlwind romance the couple got engaged but Bob got cold feet and called it off. As the years passed and they got on with their lives, both marrying other people and having families, but Avril says she always knew in her heart that one day they would be together again. One day out of the blue Avril, who was now widowed, got an email from Bob, sparking their reunion and shortly afterwards a second proposal. This time the wedding went ahead and the pair finally got their happy ending. The Long Lost Family team are looking for more lost loves like Bob and Avril. They only intend to reunite people who are currently single and happy to meet as friends … who knows, the spark might still be there. So,you want to reconnect with someone special from your past call    or email longlostloves@walltowall. . A Derry MLA has called on the British government to clary what impact the upcoming election will have on victims and survivors of historical institutional abuse. Raymond McCartney, Sinn Feins justice spokesperson, said victims needed some reassurance about what will happen now an election has been called. He added: “Sinn FeacuteinLeasUachtaraacuten Michelle O’Neill has written to the British secretary of state regarding redress for victims and survivors of historical institutional abuse. “She has told him this issue needs to be progressed without delay and that the legislation goes through before the Westminster parliament dissolves. “The victims are absolutely distraught at the prospect there might be any delays on getting legislation implemented and redress for victims resolved. googletag.cmd.push “These victims and survivors many of whom are in poor health both physically and mentally cannot be the collateral damage in a chaotic parliament. “Their hopes have been dashed on so many occasions and we all thought they were finally going to be able to get long-awaited redress for the terrible abuses they suffered at the hands of state and religious institutions. “Clarication is needed urgently on thisto ensure victims receive theredressthey are long entitled to.”  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. A week really is a long time in politics. British Prime Minister Harold Wilsons oft-quoted aphorism proved true once again this week, with the EU granting Britain yet another Brextension.March  came and went, October  the same, then, on Monday past, British Prime Minister Boris Johnston accepted Friday, January , , as the day Britain would, maybe, finally leave the EU. Undeterred by the interminable political machinations, multi- disciplinary artist, Duncan McKellar, on Simdau ast staged his “Giant Artwork Against Hard Borders” fields adjacent to Killeas Church of the Immaculate Conception.Speaking before the event, Mr McKellar said he was “very happy” with the support from the gathering local communities. He had plotted out a -metre-wide circle in two fields taking in both sides of the border with participants standing beside little bamboo markers he had placed in the ground.“It is at the same time, a protest against hard borders and a celebration of the communities around the hard borders. “Hopefully, we will end up with some nice video from the drone and some nice photographs,” he said.Mr McKellar arrived in Killea  days before the “Giant Artwork” took place and said the local “engagement” had been “fantastic.”He said: “People are enthused by the novelty of the idea. There is a palpable warmth. The Irish stereotype holds up very well.“I have been getting lots of help and lots of advice. People have been bending over backwards to help. Just this morning, Ive laid sawdust at the entrance of the field to cover up the mud and Miacuteċeaacutel, who runs the timber merchants, took it round on a truck and said, Anything I can do just let me know.”Introducing himself to the assembled crowd, Mr McKellar explained his work often used mirrors and often took place in border communities. He said: “Last year, I managed to organise a long line which stretched for  kilometre on each side of the US   Mexico border.“We also had a huge group of people on the White Clfs on March , the day Brexit was originally meant to happen. “We sent a giant SOS call to mainland Europe with our mirrors.“With the focus turning to the Northern Ireland border, I thought it was an appropriate time to come here. We are going to form a big circle, to symbolise the strength within the community here and also to show the strength of feeling against hard borders because obviously it used to be right there, the checkpoint.“We will walk to the brow of the hill. The border itself is the Liberty Burn at the bottom of the field. The sun will hit the mirrors and, as well as adding a bit of fairy dust to the images and drone footage, they symbolise the human spirit,” said Duncan.Patrick ODonnell who owns a garage in Killea said he got involved in Duncans Giant Artwork Against Hard Borders to support the artist.Patrick said: “I came along this morning to support Duncan and to protest against Brexit. The artistic aspect of the protest appealed to me.“The idea of hands across the border appealed to me. We dont want a hard border again, we dont want a border at all, basically.“As a business person, I think a hard border would be a disaster, a disaster totally,” said Patrick.The next thing Duncan has in the pipeline is maybe an installation in Palestine. googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Cornerstone City Church will next Wednesday open the doors of its new “Hope Centre” at theirrecently developed facility on Duke Street.The Derry-based church is launching the centre with the aim of helping anyone who has a practical need in their le, regardless of their background or beliefs. Available services at the Hope Centre include a food and clothing bank, debt management, counselling services and laundry and wet room utilities.The team are also currently working on phase two of the Hope Centre that will see the creation of a social supermarket, where people can purchase food at a vastly reduced rate, eat well for less food courses, a pregnancy crisis centre and employment courses on CV writing and interview skills for those who are wanting to make ato work.John Loughery,a member of the leadership team at Cornerstone City Church, said“We believe it is the responsibility of the church to reach out to those who find themselves in crisis, and help to provide them practical or emotional support. “We don’t just want to give people a one-off, hand-out, but we want to give them a helping hand to get their lives back on track, by providing them with information, education and training, where required.“We are unashamed followers of Jesus, and we want to follow His model of providing hope to the city, which is why we are opening The Hope Centre. We have read about the alarming levels of food poverty that exist in Derry and we are committed to seeing the city transformed through showing God’s love in practical way to anyone who needs it. If you or someone you know needs any help, we’d love to meet you to see how we can best help you.”The Hope Centre is partnering with local city based service providers who are working to tackle the areas of poverty, homelessness, addictions and domestic abuse.Opening hours include Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays from .am to .pm. On Wednesdays there will also be a drop-in centre open with an available team there to meet with those in need to help navigate them through the next steps of their journey. googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. More than  more young people in Derry and Coleraine came to the attention of licence inspectors in the last year, new figures have revealed. More than  young people aged  to  across the North have been interviewed by TV Licensing Visiting Officers for watching live TV or BBC iPlayer without a valid licence in , according to figures released by TV Licensing. The Belfast area, home to Queen University, St Mary’s and Stranmillis teaching colleges and the Ulster University’s Belfast campus, was the worst offender with  people interviewed here alone – a % increase on last year. TV Licensing makes more than , visits across the UK a day, focusing on unlicensed addresses where occupants have ignored previous attempts to make contact.Not all visits lead to prosecution and the majority of first-time offenders are not prosecutedthey buy a licence before their court date. Despite the explosion in popularity of smartphones and tablets, a television is still the most used device for students watching live or recorded TV, with nearly two thirds of students taking a TV to university. However, for those watching BBC iPlayer, most are using a laptop, with % watching on their portable computer and % watching on their smartphone.Sinead Doyle, spokesperson for TV Licensing, said: “Students will now have settled into their new term and every year myths circulate around about when you do and don’t need a licence. “Most students own at least one device capable of showing live TV or watching BBC iPlayer - such as a laptop, smartphone or tablet computer – it’s important they know the law around being correctly licensed, so we would encourage them to visit tvl uni to find out more.” A standard TV licence costs pound. and there are many payment options available, from paying in one go to spreading the cost over the year. title: AGM of County Down Rural Community Network group
story: THE th annual general meeting of the County Down Rural Community Network took place recently.Prior to the meeting those in attendance visited the new Saintfield Community, after which they were taken to the beautul surroundings of Castle Ward where they enjoyed a meal accompanied by the delightful harpist, Maria Boyle.Cllr Charlie Casey, chairman of Newry, Mourne and Down Council, welcomed everyone and acknowledged community volunteers and partners from across Ards, North Down, Newry, Mourne and Down and South Armagh.He paid tribute to everyone involved in Saintfield Community Centre, which he described as a ldquobrilliant example of the council working well with the community and voluntary sector to answer the need in rural areas.He said the Network was a key community partner for the council. ldquoWe have worked with you for nearly  years and this partnership has intensied in the years since the councils merged into one, he remarked.Cllr Casey said the theme of the AGM was focused on health in the broadest sense. New projects this year included social prescribing mdash helping people who present to their local GP to get out and about in their local area.New investment in multi-disciplinary teams in GP practices in Down was now being rolled out to the rest of Newry and Mourne. He said the Network was central to that roll-out and CDRCNrsquos experience of social prescribing made the organisation a great source of referrals to local community activities.Cllr Casey said CDRCN along with Community Advice and other umbrella support organisations were key to the delivery of Council services. He was grateful to the Network and especially to the hundreds of groups and thousands of volunteers who work away, day and night with no financial reward to make sure this area is a safe, pleasant and prosperous place to live, work and play.Alan Dumigan, CDRCN chairman, thanked the outgoing management committee for their time and expertise in bringing the Network forward.He acknowledged Board member Doris Noe, of Lecale Conservation, who, he said, had contributed her time, energy and expertise over the last number of years to the organisation and he wished her well in her retirement from the board.He thanked the community groups for their ongoing support and the management and staff for their continued commitment.The guest speaker, Dr Chris Leggett, recalled his long association with the community network and the exciting new developments. He acknowledged the importance of projects tackling social isolation and poverty and the need to address mental health and suicide in our local area.Nicholas McCrickard, CDRCN manager, presented the work of the organisation and reported that an increasing range of activities and projects were delivered to a high standard.He thanked the board and staff for a ldquofabulous year and acknowledged that the community and voluntary sector from Bangor to Crossmaglen was a thriving and creative place which was tackling issues relating to health, the economy, the environment and more.ldquoWorking together with the local Councils and Government departments is key to our success, he said. ldquoOur communities have a powerful voice coupled with large numbers of willing volunteers and we have risen to the challenge of tackling mental and physical health problems.The evening concluded with a talk from local photographer Raphael Mason on how photography can impact on peoplersquos physical and mental wellbeing. Attendees were treated to a video collection of captured scenery from around Co Down with collaborations from menrsquos groups..prettyPhoto

title: Ballycran’s dreams completely crushed by Dunloy demons
story: DUNLOY powered to a comprehensive victory over a game Ballycran side at the Athletic Grounds, Armagh, on Sunday to secure their place in the Ulster Club Senior Hurling Championship final against Slaughtneil.The Antrim kingpins, who recently dethroned Cushendall to get their hands on the Volunteer Cup after a -year lapse, had things very much their own way as they step up their quest for an th Ulster title success.Early scores from Keelan Molloy, Nigel Elliott and Conal Cunning gave Dunloy a - to - lead after only six minutes. Conor Woods got Ballycran moving in the eighth minute with a converted free, but Dunloy responded with two-in-a-row from Elliott and Nicky McKeague to go four points clear.Liam Savage kept Ballycran ticking over with a point from play, but a goal and a point from Cunning eased Dunloy into a - to - lead by the th minute.Woods and Cunning, via a rsquo, swapped points before Liam Savage grabbed his second score of the game in the th minute.Two further Ballycran points from Woods reduced the arrears to four points by the th minute, but Paul Shields and Chris Brogan stretched Dunloyrsquos lead to - to - after  minutes.Woods registered Ballycranrsquos seventh point in the th minute, but Dunloy finished the first half scoring with points from Shields and Cunning as the Antrim side went into the break with a commanding - to - lead.The scores should have been much closer as Ballycran registered six wides in a competitive first half.Woods opened the scoring after the break, but Ballycranrsquos uphill challenge got even harder when Gerard Hughes was given a straight red card, forcing the peninsula side to play the remainder of the game with  men.Cunning and Woods exchanged points before Ryan McGarry, Elliottand Molloy helped Dunloy storm into a - to - lead midway through the second half.A point from Liam Savage slowed Dunloy up for a while, but they quickly regained the initiative and points from Elliott, Eamon Smyth, Cunning and McKeague had the Cuchullains - to - ahead with six minutes remaining.Woods scored a late point for Ballycran, but it was quickly cancelled out by points from Molloy and McKeague and a goal at the death from Anton McGrath to put the game to bed.Ballycran: Stephen Keith, Michael Hughes, Sean Ennis, Gerard Hughes, Brett Nicholson, Padraig Flynn, Patrick Hughes, Liam Savage , Phelim Savage, Scott Nicholson, Conor Woods , Michael Ennis, Stuart Martin, Colum McManus, Chris Egan. Subs: James Coyle for McManus, Brendan Ennis for Martin, Cormac McAllister for Scott Nicholson, Niall Breen for Egan,Dunloy: R Elliott, P Duffin, C McKinley, Kevin Molloy, E Smyth , R McGarry , K McKeague, P Shields , C Kinsella, N Elliott , N McKeague , C Brogan , E OrsquoNeill , C Cunning , Keelan Molloy . Subs: Anton McGrathfor Cunning, Gabriel McTaggart for Brogan, Sean Ellliott for OrsquoNeill, R Molloy for Keelan Molloy, James McKeague for Shields..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch PS are champions
story: THE top five qualying local primary schools competed for the Ballynahinch Cup last week.Qualying for finals day were Holy Family PS, St. Patricks PS, Ballynahinch PS, Cedar IPS and St. Francisrsquos PS Drumaroad.The tournament was run on a league basis and although close between the second to fth places, the winners were out on a dferent level.Ballynahinch Primary School, under the guidance of principal and manager Michael Moore, took the honours in style with their excellent performances catching the eye of everyone on show.To win all your games is no mean feat, but thatrsquos exactly what the Ballynahinch lads did.Both Benjamin and Rory stole the show for Ballynahinch PS with their clever, interlinking passes which created scoring opportunities for both themselves and their team-mates.The new idea of localised tournaments leading into larger NMD ones has so far been a massive success. For the champions to be able to walk to the venue, do the business and walk back again was dferent.Delivering the event on the day was new local coach Nathan Heath. Having grown up in the game and coaching now for many years, Nathan has furthered his development with new ideas around schools and club football.The tournament was made possible by local partners coming together to ensure the dayrsquos proceedings were a successful one..prettyPhoto

title: Call for security gates
story: COUNCIL officials have been accused of dragging their feet in providing gates and security fences to protect pensioners living in a Downpatrick housing estate.The Model Farm Community Association has condemned what it describes as ldquorepeated delays by Newry, Mourne and Down Council in erecting the planned gates and fences near pensionersrsquo homes in the Ballymote Walk area.The area has been blighted by repeated outbreaks of anti-social behaviour by unruly teenagers and residents say gates and fencing are vital for their protection.Temporary steel and wooden barriers were put in place two years ago, but they have been damaged and repaired on numerous occasions.Association chairperson Kyla Hannaway slammed what she described as an ldquooverly bureaucratic approach for causing the delays.She said the delays were in spite agreement being reached after consultation with the police, Housing Executive, Department for Infrastructure, Ambulance Service and other agencies.ldquoIt was agreed with all the other partners that urgent action needed to be taken and the Housing Executive found a budget to block up most of the back alleys, Ms Hannaway remarked.ldquoThe delays this year are down to the council re-starting the consultation process with the interagency partners and the residents all over again where they could have used the consultations completed by the Housing Executive last year.Local pensioner Deirdre Smyth said: ldquoWe are a forgotten minority up here. We are being terrorised in our homes and our property is being damaged.Mrs Smyth said it was almost impossible to report incidents to the police.ldquoIf we can get through the police often donrsquot respond, she continued. ldquoThese temporary gates have been being put up for almost two years now. Torn down and put up again. Itrsquos the residents who suffer, not the council people for delays in signing off on the workthat needs to be done.The residents are being supported by local Independent councillor Cadogan Enright, who accused the council of being ldquonot exactly on top of their game.He said: ldquoThe need for fences and gates to make the area into a cul-de-sacs was triggered by an emergency situation where pensioners were and still are under siege by a small number of nersquoer-do-wells, culminating with the actual burning down of a pensionerrsquos cottage.ldquoThe council have not been treating this as an emergency. Were it not for the Housing Executive repeatedly replacing the eight temporary steel and wood barriers week after week when they are torn down, the area would be unviable as an area where pensioners can live.He added: ldquoI have proposed a workshop between the social partners led by the PSNI, Housing Executive, council and other partners to agree in detail a step-by-step process for gating orders in writing so that we never again have such a series of dreadful delays.A spokesman for the council said last night: Newry, Mourne and Down District Council can advise that the Northern Ireland Housing Executive has applied to the council for gating orders in the Model Farm area and that the Council is currently following gating order guidance produced by the Department of the Environment.ldquoThis process requires consultation with the Department for Infrastructure and members of the public in the area. A public advertisement of the proposals is then required. It is expected that this process will be complete in December .ldquoThe Policing and Community Safety Partnershiphas increased the number of Community Safety Warden patrols in this area over the last few weeks as a deterrent to reports of anti-social behaviour.ldquoThe PCSP will continue to work in partnership with the PSNI to ensure that warden patrols are appropriately deployed across the Newry, Mourne and Down District Council area where reports of anti-social behaviour have been received..prettyPhoto

title: Fond farewell to council chief
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council have bade farewell to their retiring chief executive, Mr Liam Hannaway.The celebratory event, which was hosted by council chairman Charlie Casey took place last Tuesday at Killeavy Castle, near Newry.Paying tribute on the evening, Cllr Casey reflected on Mr Hannawayrsquos many years in public service and his dedication to Newry, Mourne and Down Council.He said: ldquoLiam has spent  years in public service. Appointed as chief executive to the council in , he led the council through the biggest restructure of local government since .ldquoHe amalgamated the councils of Newry and Mourne District Council and Down District Council, putting into place new governance and management structures, ensuring that there was no break in service to the residents of the district.ldquoWith his wealth of experience and knowledge, and with a deep commitment to the betterment of the district, Liam has worked with local councillors and staff, and leaves the council with the foundations to develop and excel.Cllr Casey said that under Mr Hannawayrsquos leadership the council had made strides in delivering for all the people in the district.ldquoThere has been a % increase in visitor spend to our area, he said. ldquoThe Community Plan framework and the seven District Electoral Area Forums have been created. New jobs and businesses have been created and promoted and both Newry and Downpatrick have seen state-of-the-art leisure centres opened.ldquoCrucial partnerships have been agreed, including working as a key partner in the Belfast Region City Deal, which will bring a transformation in our infrastructure, tourism and regeneration.Cllr Casey added: ldquoAs Liam retires, I would want to thank him for his many years of service and wish both him and his family every success in the future..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C October 30%2C 1979
story: HOUSING mdash A pound million-plus programme for the maintenance of , Housing Executive homes in Down District was announced this week.The schedule of works is the first in the Down area to be drawn up by the Housing Executive to switch the emphasis from lsquoresponse maintenancersquo to lsquopreventative maintenancersquo.The programme will include the complete rehabilitation of many homes and work will include roof insulation and repainting as well as the replacement of internal woodwork, windows, baths, heating and electrical wiring, as required.The Housing Executiversquos regional controller, Mr Colin James, stressed that in each house the work done would obviously depend on the condition of the house structure or items within the house.ldquoNot every house will need everything replace mdash what we call the lsquoall frontsrsquo approach In many homes we will be replacing only those items that have seen better days.Mr James said priority had been given to the oldest estates where houses are generally in a bad state of repair and had not already had electrical re-wiring.The programme basically covers houses which are at least  years old but Mr James admitted that by no means are all the old estates admitted.ldquoWe cannot pretend wersquove covered all the worst areas but this is a start. We will eventually cover all old estates, subject to continuing funds and satisfactory contracts.Movements have already been made with the awarding of a number of pre-paint repair contracts and work on all contracts should begin by March or April next year.More programmes of maintenance work are being prepared and will be starting in the - financial year, subject to the approval of the Executiversquos Board.CASTLEWELLAN mdash Uncertainty has surrounded the recent proposals to establish units for educationally sub-normal pupils at Castlewellan.The South Eastern Education and Library Board give approval in January for two new units to be set up at the local controlled primary school.However, plans were revised when the neighbouring school, St Malachyrsquos Primary, decided it wanted to have special ESN units.Board officers decided thatan ESN unit is established at St Malachyrsquos the demand for ESN facilities at Castlewellan Primary mightand therefore only one unit might be necessary at each school.But confusion arose when the Board placed advertisements in a local newspaper about the plans to establish the units.Castlewellan councillor, Mrs Ethel Smyth, a Board member, was unsure about whether or not the Board had changed its policy and was intended to establish the units at St Malachyrsquos instead of at the controlled school.Mrs Smyth, who has raised the matter on several occasions, told Board members, this week that she was aggrieved about the whole affair and thought that Board officers had acted in a ldquovery surreptitious manner.ldquoThis sort of thing raises suspicions in the community and itrsquos just not good enough,: said Mrs Smyth.However, she was assured by Board chairman, Mr Cecil Kirkwood, that Board officers had not acted in an underhand manner and that there had only been a misunderstanding.KILLYLEAGH mdash A Killyleagh priest had called this week for people to follow the example of friendship shown by more than  Protestants and Roman Catholics who joined together in a special Halloween dinner and concert organised by his church.He is Fr Hugh OrsquoHagan and he was speaking hours after  senior citizens had enjoyed a dinner and concert in St Maryrsquos Hall, organised by the hall management committee.Speaking afterwards Fr OrsquoHagan said that Killyleagh and Shrigley had a unique community, ldquo everywhere has like here, Northern Ireland would be a more peaceful place.Invitations to Thursdayrsquos dinner and concert went out to both sides of the community and Fr OrsquoHagan stressed that he hoped no senior citizen had been forgotten, either Protestant or Roman Catholic.The idea of the dinner mdash which was such a success last year, when he was held for the first time mdash has been widely praised in the town, especially by the senior citizens and Thursday nightrsquos was no exception, with many voting it a big hit.Before the dinner began, Fr OrsquoHagan mdash who has been priest in Killyleagh for over  years and who is the longest serving priest ever in the town mdash welcomed everyone and thanked them for coming.He welcomed especially, the three ministers in the town, the Rev J C Boggs, Rev J D Mark and Rev R E Conn. Also Lady Pym who was representing the local senior citizensrsquo Friendship Club.BALLYGALGET mdash A request from the school management committee of St Patrickrsquos Primary School at Ballygalget to provide transport for  pupils has been turned down by the local Education Board.The school management committee had explained to the Board that the  infants end their school day officially at .pm, but there is no transport to take them home until .pm.The school committee requested action because there was no teacher available to supervise the infants who had to remain in the school building.The transport officer of the Board, Mr Milligan, stressed that seven of the children were below compulsory school attendance age and as such were not eligible for school transport.Outlining the background to transport facilities provided at the school, Mr Milligan pointed out that an Ulsterbus had carried the children to and from the school for over  years.It had not generally been the practice of the Board to provide buses to take the children home before the end of the normal school day and there were no Board vehicles free to provide transport.Despite a y debate, the Boardrsquos Educational Services Committee said they could not suggest a solution to the problem.DOWNPATRICK mdash Downpatrick priest Dr Joseph Maguire has been re-elected chairman of the finance committee of the South Eastern Education and Library Board.Dr Maguire told members of the committee that he considered it an hour to be re-elected and he promised to serve the interests of the committee and the Board in every way that he could.COMBER mdash Proposals by Comber traders to prevent moves which they say could threaten their businesses, may well be turned down.The threat is in the shape of the Department of Environment who have announced that they intend introducing parking restrictions in the main shopping areas of the town.The confrontation between the Department and Comber Traders Association has been long running, but on Thursday it seemed that a solution could be found.The Traders Association had an on-the-spot meeting on Thursday morning with a representative from the Roads Division, who listened to the tradersrsquo complaints and suggestions for the siting of the yellow lines in the town. Also present was a representative from the RUC traffic branch.However, there are fears that the tradersrsquo suggestions will be dismissed and the Department will push ahead with their proposals to restrict parking in Comber.The Traders Association feel that the proposals are a very real threat to their livelihood and are inconvenient mdash a view shared by many residents in the town who have backed the Association in their fight with the Department..prettyPhoto

title: Greenkeeper gets revenge at sunny Spa
story: SPA golfers faced a novel end-of-season challenge on Saturday when head groundsman Lee Cartmill set up the -hole course for his Greenkeeperrsquos Revenge competition.It was essentially a fun event which attracted a large number of both ladies and gents and proved to be so popular it is likely to feature again on the Spa calendar.But the devilishly dficult pin placings did not deter Alan Carson who topped the leaderboard with a magnicent score of  points while Catherine McEvoy won the ladies -hole competition with  points.Spa PGA professional Gary Wardlow warned competitors that the pins were in ldquorather unusual positions but after a number of impressive scores were ed he reckoned it had not been sufficiently challenging.Stuart Alexander had his best start for many months with eight straight pars followed by a birdie at the par four th, but unfortunately his great run did not continue.At least two other competitors mdash Sam Boyd and William McAnally mdash also had birdies at the th where the pin was placed in the left-hand green side bunker.Menrsquos results: st Alan Carson , nd George Wilson , rd Chris Chittick , th Stephen Adams , th Brian Graham .Ladiesrsquo results: st Catherine McEvoy , nd Vivienne Abernethy , rd Carol Shields ..prettyPhoto

title: Hat trick of titles
story: IT was a case of trebles all round recently for a highly-talented teenager from Kilmore.Eighteen year-old Conor Mullan, a son of well-known Crossgar garage owner James Mullan, was in seventh heaven after adding the Ulstermotocross semi-expert title to the Irish and Ulster Youth crowns won earlier in the the year.Conor blazed his way to victory in all three competitions and crowned a sensational year at Desertmartin last week when he clinched the Ulster title, despite riding with a few niggling injuries, including a troublesome shoulder.To clinch Ulster and Irish titles in the same year is some achievement and Conor has done it in style.The Year  pupil at St Patrickrsquos Grammar School, Downpatrick, now has his focus on sitting his A-Levels next year ldquoI am in Upper Sixth at the minute, taking A-Levels in geography, technology and business studies, he said.ldquoNext year the plan is to go to university, where Irsquod like to study business, or economics. I would like to go to Queenrsquos or Jordanstown, as I am a bit of a home bird.ldquoI havenrsquot thought too far ahead at the minute, but education is certainly the priority and then I can concentrate on racing, he added.While Conor concentrates on his studies he also has his future sorted out in motocross.ldquoI would also like to be based at home for racing, but also take on new challenges racing in England, he enthused.ldquoNext year I will be moving up into the experts class and I would like to be in the top five finishing places. In England I would like to take part in the MX Nationals again, where I will be aiming for a few podium finishes, as I came close to it last year. So, maybe this year with a bit of hard work I can take another step up, he continued.Looking a little bit further ahead, Conor has his sights set on taking part in some big events.ldquoTowards the end of next year I would like to have a go racing in the full Maxis British Championship and I would like to thank Roger Magee and the Hitachi KTM UK Racing Team for all of the support that they have given me so far in my career, he added.ldquoI would also like to thank BLRC, McGrady Insurance, Quinns, Cosy Roof, Mauds, Shortcross Gin  Function Design for their kind sponsorship..prettyPhoto

title: Local politicians meet with City Deal partners
story: A NUMBER of local politicians have met with their other partners in the Belfast City Deal partnership for the first time to review progress on plans for millions of pounds investment in a number of key areas.The City Deal will see the UK Government invest poundm into the Belfast Region over the next  years and itrsquos proposed that this figure will be matched by Northern Ireland government departments.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is one of five local authorities paired with Belfast City Council, universities and the private sector who have committed poundm to help deliver a raft of schemes, with the remainder of the cash coming from the Treasury and Northern Ireland Executive.City deals are packages of funding and decision making powers which allow councils to boost the economy through the development of large projects in their respective areas.The deals are designed to allow councils to take charge and responsibility of decisions that affect their area, do what they think is best to help businesses grow, create economic growth and decide how public money should be spent.Last week, the Belfast Region City Deal Council Panel met for the first time to review progress as business cases are prepared for this transformative programme of regional investment.Alderman Brian Kingston mdash who chaired the rsquos meeting mdash said the success in securing the first City Deal in Northern Ireland is due to the unprecedented levels of collaboration between councils, universities, regional further education colleges, government and private sector partners.He continued: ldquoOur focus as a council  will be continuing to embed that collegiate approach as we progress business cases for our  ambitious projects and an underpinning employability and skills programme.ldquoA successful City Deal is about so much more than our inidual areas ndash itrsquos about working together to ensure that we benefit people living in the whole region ndash so that we connect them to more and better jobs and opportunities, and attract investment to the region. Together, we want to deliver inclusive, transformative regional regeneration, strengthen our economy and boost our prosperity.Ambitious plans to revolutionise tourist facilities in Newcastle are part of the City Deal proposals and are making signicant progress.Ground condition survey work is taking place in the resort at the base of the Mournes where a new a gondola ride into the heart of the mountains would be based, with the local council confirming that it is planning to appoint a dedicated team to deliver an outline business case designed to pave the way to secure funding to help build the project.An economist is also to be appointed to help with the delivery of the business case which is expected to be completed in early spring or summer.The Gateway proposal is one of the key projects included in the local councilrsquos bid for a share of poundbn investment package under the Belfast City Regional Deal.The world class tourist attraction proposals include the gondola ride into the heart of the Mournes and an ultra-modern visitor centre at the site of the old quarry at Thomasrsquo Mountain with the proposals expected to be delivered with the help of a range of funding partners to signicantly increase the number of visitors to the resort.Other proposals include an Alpine coaster ride enabling people to hurtle down the side of the mountain on a single track in a buggy.Newry, Mourne and Down is hoping to secure poundm from the Northern Ireland Executive and is committing poundm of ratepayersrsquo money to fund the proposed gondola ride and visitor centre.Council officials are also working alongside Tourism NI to secure financial backing for other aspects of the tourism investment and support to move the ious projects through a series of key stages, including the preparation of business cases and planning approval.Other aspects of the scheme include an elevated tree top walk in Tollymore Forest Park, a new visitor centreand bird hide at the Murlough Nature Reserve and a new bridge constructed under the main Kilkeel Road at the Bloody Bridge on the outskirts of the town..prettyPhoto

title: Lorcán’s gift of life
story: A DOWNPATRICK couple is celebrating after learning that a le-extending drug will be made available free for their young son who has cystic fibrosis.Jen Banks and her husband Dermot were told yesterday by the Department of Health that Northern Ireland would follow the lead by NHS England and make Cystic Fibrosisdrugs Orkbambi, Symkevi and Kalydeco available to eligible patients.It is hoped that their two year-old son, Lorcaacuten, and other CF sufferers will be offered the drugs within weeks.The initial cost of a yearrsquos supply of the drug was estimated at pound, per patient.Last night Jen told the Recorder that she and her husband were ldquoecstatic but the news still has sunk in after they were called to a meeting with Permanent Health Secretary Richard Pengelly at Stormont.The surprise announcement came as the couple were preparing to import the generic drug from South America as part of a CF Buyers Club of families.In a desperate attempt to start their son on the drug as quickly as possible, the couple and their family fundraised around pound, to buy Lorcaacuten three months treatment.ldquoWe were so close to getting the generic drug ourselves and that would have been great as Lorcaacuten would have started on it, but we would have still been campaigning and pushing for it, said Jen.ldquoWe have been told that the Department of Health want to copy what NHS England did and get the drug into peoplersquos hands within  days, starting rightly so, with those most in need.The mother of two admitted that living with Lorcaacutenrsquos condition and knowing that there was a drug that could dramatically improve his quality of le was ldquoabsolutely horrendous.ldquoIn many ways we feel that Lorcaacutenrsquos infancy has been stolen from us, Jen said of her first child who was diagnosed at  days old.ldquoThe torture wasnrsquot that he had CF, it was that there was something that could help him but there was a company out there that was pricing the drug so highly, it was unobtainable.Jen believes that Lorcaacuten will be on the drug before Christmas and recognises this as a gt of le.ldquoItrsquos not that this is just a good Christmas present but that we have actually been given extra Christmases with our son, said Jen.ldquoOne of the models for the drugs suggest thatyou start it at age six, you can have an extra  years on top of the normal le expectancy for a CF sufferer. ldquoItrsquos like we have been given  Christmases with Lorcaacuten, that it what it really means to us.Lorcaacuten currently needs two sessions of physio each day and uses a nebuliser five times a day along with  tables to absorb fat from his food.He has been fighting off the pseudomonas infection since last Christmas.Jen said: ldquoHopefully, by taking the drugs, it will mean that will be the end of the infection and he wonrsquot get other infections.ldquoIt gives us even more time to keep him healthy until the better drugs come along.The  year-old has been one of the most vocerous campaigners to have the drug make available in Northern Ireland.She and her husband planned over the summer to move to Louth as the drug is
